nodes.bodyText:
Introspection mock similar to what @loicmathieu did.
This introspection url is learned from /auth/realms/quarkus/.well-known/openid-configuration discovery
Discovery mock that notifies quarkus the introspection_path
@cemnura We need to return a different token value (say 456) here and differentiate an introspection response, see more on it below

@cemnura what should be done here is to check if the incoming token is equal to 123 and if yes then return this response, it should be done anyway, without the expired token check, as it has to be tested that it is indeed a 123 token which is being introspected.
Once it works then it will be easy to check if this token is equal to 456 and if yes then return the response with the expired value set to some low value, less than the issued at time etc :-)

I think I got it.
When there is a Authorization header with a value equal to 123 is sent then the current valid response is returned. In other cases then the response returns the response with the expired value set to some low value.
Hi @cemnura it will be in a POST body: token=123 etc

@cemnura Can we have a different KeycloakTestResource for the introspection endpoint, we need to keep it simple for the users :-), i.e, if the users want to test JWT, they don't need to set the introspection path (in most cases) and likewise for the opaque tokens. Please add KeycloakOpaqueTokenTestResource instead
It is not in the header, but in the POST payload

+        // define the mock for the introspect endpoint
+        WireMock.stubFor(WireMock.post("/auth/realms/quarkus/protocol/openid-connect/token/introspect")
